comment_body.4:
Reposted from last week’s thread:

My friend is the one buying, but I’m helping him with this decision as well. Here’s what I know based on what he has told me:

Location: Nevada, USA

Price range: $15,000 - $30,000

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: New

Type of vehicle: Hot hatch or coupe

Must haves: Must be decently quick, must be fun to drive (presumably good handling), and must have a manual transmission. Some storage space would be nice but it’s not as important as the other listed factors.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual

Intended use: Daily driving, including occasional 2+ hour road trips, possible track use

Vehicles you've already considered: Honda Civic Si Coupe, Hyundai Veloster N, Subaru WRX STI (probably too expensive), Golf GTI, Honda Civic Type R (He wants this more than anything else but it’s a bit out of his price range)

Is this your 1st vehicle: No, but it will be his first new vehicle

Do you need a Warranty: Yes, unless he finds a Type R for a low price

Can you do minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: We negotiated with some Hyundai salesmen and got the 2020 Veloster N with the performance package down to $30k from the $35k they were originally asking due to “market adjustment,” AKA dealer markup. Monthly payment after negotiations would have been $400/mo. We walked because they wanted 9% APR and wouldn’t budge since my friend is a first-time buyer. It actually may not be too late to claim this deal, but should we have walked? We’re both rather young and completely inexperienced car buyers, so we fear they may be trying to get over on us.
comment_body.6:
2020 Pacifica or Odyssey?

We’re going to be replacing our 2015 Odyssey EX-L (which were giving to a relative) with a new Minivan. We’re trying to decide between the Pacifica and another Odyssey. FWIW, we’ve not been impressed with the build quality of the Odyssey though we gather Chrysler probably won’t be better.

Part of our issue is that we need 8 seats since we fold the entire back row on trips for luggage and have one parent in the 2Nd row with two kids.

The Pacifica lets us get the features we want on lower trims, but the 8 seater limits availability because the default is 7. Odyssey has 8 by default but you have to go up to the top trims

The pacific also does somewhat worse though not a lot worse in crash tests.

We’re not really considering the Sienna at this time, and it looks like it’s at least a year out from proper refresh

I walk to work 90% of the time and all the research I've done has said that Priuses which sit will have battery problems. So, I thought I might as well get something fun that won't have issues if it sits for around a week at a time.

I just started learning manual and wanted to make the jump to it. I just test drove an automatic and manual BRZ (which the dealer told me I was pretty good at manual for spending an hour of my life total in one before), but definitely need to still learn and get comfortable with stick. I do not have anyone I can learn on their cars, which means my natural conclusion is to buy a car and force myself to learn. I enjoyed the BRZ, but it was a bit too small for me. Now I'm stuck watching youtube videos about WRX reliability and similar cars (Veloster N, Civic Si, etc).

I know everybody's got an opinion on VW, but I personally know 3 or 4 people who own them and love them. I really think it depends on if/how you take care of your car.

I think this is a great deal if I can get it. $12,900 with 16,700 miles. I'll drive it into the ground and I only do about 10,000 miles a year or less. For the VW people: are they easy to do minor work on? People say maintenance is expensive/a pain, but I want to hear from some DIY people like me. If so, what are some good resources for VWs? Is there a lot on the good ol' interwebs? Manuals I should have? (This would be my first VW)

Thanks in advance!
